author: codetheweb

description.text:
Elbow.scad
A parametric elbow or simple shoulder joint. Designed to be a joint in an articulated robot arm, it can be used to form many hinged structures, including gates, covers, support bars in baby carts etc. It will allow you to hide wires etc. inside the mechanism, making the arm appear very simple, while the underlying system may be quite complex. Quentin Harley 2012, GPLv2

Change the parameters to match the support pipe to the PVC or other piping you will use for the arm sections.  The support pipe has 3mm thick walls, so the inner diameter should be 6mm less than the outer
Print two for each elbow joint. Use two 608 bearings and place in the bearing recesses in the one half of the joint, and secure the other half to the 8mm threaded rod using 20mm washers in the bearing recesses.

comments.text: Converted it to STL, and printed in PLA, 0.67 scale, .2 layer height, with supports, and it fits 1/2" schedule 40 pvc nicely.

description.text: BMW E46 dash trim mounting clip. Part number: 51458266814 - Insert Rot.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jFflbOjSeiv

Building a homemade electric bike using 3D printed parts! It was definitely a learning curve, but it worked out pretty well! https://youtu.be/9rIIJbDkpN8

If you would like to build the same setup, I have listed the parts required below. As mentioned in the video, I would really appreciate it if you purchased the parts via my affiliate links to support my work. Thanks!

Parts List
Bike: https://goo.gl/h2GIVm (UK)
https://goo.gl/MNdU2O (USA)
3D Printed parts:
Motor: https://goo.gl/3HFwXg
VESC: http://vedder.se/2015/01/vesc-open-source-esc/
Electric scooter throttle: https://goo.gl/yvloKG
Saddle bag: https://goo.gl/ilyxSJ
6s 5000mah li-po battery
HTD5 12T pulley (with 8mm bore for motor shaft)
HTD5 800x15mm belt
5pcs m4x30mm bolts (clamp motor mount to frame)
4pcs m4x10mm bolts (attach motor to mount)
1pcs m4x50mm bolt (roller bearings seat on this bolt)
5pcs m4 nyloc nuts
3pcs m3x10mm bolts (assembly of electronics case)
5mm wide cable ties (attach pulley to spokes)
EC5 battery connectors
4mm bullet connectors (for ESC)
Basic knowledge of electronics and soldering
and a 3D printer...

Also, the VESC is capable of using the electric scooter 'analog signal' and an input, so the arduino isn't required.

Note: The 3D printed brackets/pulley were designed specifically for the bike used in the video, it will not fit any other bike and I will not be modifying it on request to fit to other bikes.

Disclaimer: I do not hold responsibility for any wrongful riding if you chose to build this ebike. It is beyond the legal limit (250w) for an electric bike, which is why I chose to ride it within the grounds of my university.

comments.text:
Just wanted to say to anyone wanting to make the 'vesc' signal you require to feed to the speed controller is a standard RC PWM signal which can be easily generated by any cheap servo tester - so, no electronics knowledge is really required.
Just google "RC Servo Tester".
You would need to find a safe way to cobble it to the handlebars - with some 'deadmans handle' arranglement (don't even think about doing it without) - so maybe keep the electric bike grips.
Note also that the ESC will probably not 'arm' unless first supplied with a zero throttle at power-up, Some ESC's also require a 0% >25% - 0% "blip" of the throttle to arm.
Be safe - a motor this size could easily take a finger off.

title: Aquarium Planter / Fish Hospital
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to create a planter of sorts for my aquarium. Some people convert their HOB (Hang on Back) filters to hold plants, but I don't have any HOB filters though I still wanted to benefit from the water filtering plants can do within an aquarium and created this box which is meant to be hung inside and protect the roots and stems from being eaten. Can probably use some bio media on the bottom as well.

It may be a bit too big and took a long time to print so it could probably use some refining but this was my first attempt at modeling anything and it works for me.

With the size of this it could also feasibly be used as a time out/resting/hospital cage for any fish that might need it.

author: dhoyt7141

description.text:
The kid wanted a doorbell that could play Hawaii 50 theme song. It sounded like such an easy project..

http://www.leftcoast.biz/iWeb/Left_Coast/The_doorbell.html

Paint & sand & paint & sand &..

I used primer paint, coated the parts, then sanded the first couple times with 120 grit. 3 or 4 coats to fill the "grain" and get a somewhat smooth surface. The last couple coats were sanded at 220 grit because things were getting smoother. Then, at last, I'd spray on the top coat.

You never really do get all the grain out, but that's ok. If you did, you'd be getting into the "fill" layers and that would be a nightmare!

Also I used a foam sanding block. This is important. Use a block to level stuff out.

As for paint I used name brand, rattle can spray paint.

Actually there is a writeup..

Here's the link : http://www.leftcoast.biz/iWeb/Left_Coast/The_doorbell.html
test for printing

title: Mendel Extruder Bracket and Quick Release Spool Holder

description.text:
Designed for the early (legacy) Reprappro Mendel. If you built one of these then you probably have a lot of redundant 8mm nuts on the top bars, an extruder mounted inconveniently on the side and nowhere to keep your filament!
This provides a bracket to re-mount your extruder on the top bars and also provides a filament spool holder. Designed for 16cm diameter spools although a 20cm diameter spool will just fit. To release the spool just flex the support brackets apart.

The bar through the spool is some old steel wardrobe clothes pole that I had in the garage. The inside diameter must be greater than 16mm (that's the size of the protrusions on the support brackets).
The extruder bracket has some pads to hold it down if you print in ABS (It's quite big and has little area in contact with the bed). The pads are easy to cut off after printing.

title: Stop Sign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Want to learn OpenSCAD and I need a couple of stop signs. I plan on also learning how to do filament switches and print this with red base and white top. Or if I'm lazy print red and paint the raised border and text white.

Included the scad file.

Why isn't it customizable?

Because of the font and the formulas I use it's not worth making customizable. I tried. But for a stop sign you need a narrow (tall) font. Looks like the one I picked isn't available here.

Specs

Based on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stop_sign#Specifications
Width = 750mm (100%)
Border = 20mm (2.7%)
Text Heigth = 250mm (33%)

And simply scaled it down.

OpenSCAD

Designed in OpenSCAD with spheres and some hacky math to get things rotated.
It's got variables so you can change:

  • sides = number of sides (works up to 12)
  • height = total height of the sign
  • width = diamenter of the sphere
  • edge_width = the width of the border (default 2.7% of width)
  • txt = the text (default "STOP")
  • txt_font = the font to use (default "Lohit Telugu")
  • txt_size = size of the font (defaults to about 59% of width)

author: jewzaam

description.text: bitcoin use as glass or pen holder

Fitness is a problem for people with chronic computer addiction. I found I spent too much time sitting on my bum and not getting even enough basic exercise. I had my son's bicycle handed up to me so I bought a bike stand with built in magnetic resistance (I chose one that provided a replacement axle bolt as well so that the stand matched the wheel nuts exactly).

I had a Mega2560 with a 3.2 Sainsmart Touch Display at my disposal so I rigged up this bicycle computer to monitor my effort. The added circuitry is extremely simple with only two wires to the reed switch required. I have found a moderate distance twice a day is very beneficial to the circulation in my lower legs, and gets into the aerobic range as well.

The two printed objects, the Mega mount and the reed switch mount are pretty much bread and butter efforts but do the job and may inspire others to improve the designs. I have used a proprietary reed switch ready mounted in a holder, and the magnet (on the spokes) that went with it. I had put these aside from a commercial bicycle computer a few years ago. If you don't have these, then I have adding an extra hole in the reed switch mount to take a standard mini magnetic reed switch.

The Arduino program is also pretty basic, but at the moment proves the principle and I am looking to improve it to make my exercises more interesting. Please use the UTFT library mentioned in the Arduino program. It works! My long term goal would be to use the computer to control the magnetic resistance system built into the bike stand. This way the effort required could be changed automatically or randomly to simulate hills etc

If this was to be mounted on a road bike and used in really riding through the country side I would imagine the whole thing would need to be beefed up and maybe even a water proof cover etc. I am sure this should not be "Sport and Outdoors", ho hum, anyway have fun!

Extra Info

I used small self tapping screws to hold the Arduino Mega board directly onto the plastic mount. I used a thin elastic (bungey) cord to tie the mount on to the handlebars and yoke. (see the two center holes). This works fine for a stationery exercise bicycle, but would need to be improved greatly for a bicycle out on the roads or tracks.

I used a three prong header (0.1") that had the connectors bent to a right angle. That way the connections could be made to pins 21 and 19 with out hitting the display board above it.

I have provided a small vertical hole for the reed switch.

A small piece of double sided foam tape (mine was white) was used to secure the reed relay and stop it from twisting or slipping around (eg into the spokes!!)

author: homer75

description.text:
I dropped out the side guards from the front (See Large Hive Final2) This was stronger and the guards broke pretty easily. I recommend printing this file along with the separated tray files.

This is an edited version from the first Mason Bee Hive design. The last one was pretty small and there were a few things that others thought would make it better. I talked with a few people who knew more than me, and came up with a few design changes. The holes are now circular, there are more holes, and the holes are a bit deeper. We also widened the holes to allow for a paper roll to go in.

I ended up having trouble with the size of the files when printing so I added a file of a single center tray and a file of both end trays. (Using all interior trays won't hurt anything except for my OCD)

Thanks for the feedback and let us know how this works for you.

comments.text: I was having troubles with the large file for the trays.  I broke them down so that both of the end (Outside) trays are in one file, and the inner trays are each going to be printed off of the same file one at a time.  I hope this helps people with smaller printers.

title: Modular FR632 VRX Tripod Ground Station

description.text:
I Designed this modular FR632 Tripod mount for my ground station. It requires no supports and no tools or other screws. Everything can be printed in PETG or PLA (with Higher infill or thicker walls) except FR632OrganizerCase.stl. That has to be printed in TPU because it stretches over the FR632 and also has flexible compartments to organize wires.

Assembly Video: https://youtu.be/kauQAPGGCMM

Update #5 4/26/17: Goggle holder has been enlarged to allow for Fatsharks and other goggles to be hung face down and not from the strap.

Update #4 4/1/17: More Symmetrical, There's now a hexagon hole instead of half circle so the top piece can be reversed. Made another hole on the bottom of the FR632 case to allow for more inputs and use less plastic. Enlarged front opening for less plastic. Made Goggle and Battery mounts thicker after some "stress testing". Finally, the Universal Screen mount V1.0 is also uploaded now. all it needs is a rubber band and it will slide back and forth to hold most screens. I've realized that thicker screens don't fit very well and that will be addressed in a newer version.

Update #3 3/24/17: Added Goggle Holder! Enlarged the Insert and Top piece, made it symmetrical front to back so that the battery and goggle mounts can be reversed.

Update #2 3/21/17: Battery Holder is a success! file added, next up, goggle holder.

Update #1 3/21/17: Made the Insert and Top fatter, was a little scared of how thin it was. Battery Mount is nearly done, test print is going now.

Robo 3D

title: iPadAir iPadAir2 iPadPro grip and bumpers

description.text:
This solves a problem with the iPadAir2 - having the left hand wander onto the screen while holding and reading it. Invariably, the article being read either jumps back to the top, or closes. The grip also partially protects the screen from falls. It gives a place to store the Apple Pencil while not being used, with a separate compartment for the spare ends and adapter.
The left side bezel of the iPad isn’t wide enough to hold the iPad comfortably with the left hand while reading for long periods. The iPad slides snugly into this grip, giving a wider left bezel. The thumb area has a raised ridge near the top to keep the thumb from wandering onto the screen.
If you need an iPadAir grip, scale the .stl file. The iPadAir2 is 6.1mm thick. The Air is 7.6mm.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Resolution:

medium

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bumper corners and camera cover are printed at least 3 at a time on a 10 outline skirt for bed adhesion. Position the skirts close enough so they touch each other for better bed adhesion. 3 units give each a chance to cool before the next layer. I printed 2 layers top and bottom and 1 layer perimeter, 15% infill.

Cleanup for the corners can be done with a knife, or scissors. Simply cut off the printer guides, sand if needed.

description.text: This adds a secure hole to the Garrett Pro-Pointer (first gen) which was included in future Pro-Pointer revisions. I tested another version (Not the linked one but looks the same design) but it was too loose and flimsy so I decided to design a different style. I tried for the lowest profile with keeping up the strength of the ring and hole. It is slightly threaded to fit over the threads snuggly, and is best put on without the o-ring and then add it back on when completed. I just wanted to share what I made in hopes someone else could also find some use. It will require some sort of spacer as laffranchi63 added, which I haven't added in yet. I ended up finding a plastic quarter and am using it as my battery spacer, it seemed only appropriate. Thanks!

Modified the Anet A8 Led Ring Holder by bigvlad to use the extruder fan mounting screws for easier access. No need to disassemble the print head in order to mount this bracket. Be careful of interference with z-axis coupler on the left side. Depending on how high up you put your coupler, and where on the z-axis the head is when the x-axis is homed, you might end up with some interference.

author: thwaker

print_settings.Notes:: I used ABS but I think PLA is more rigid and would probably work better. I used a lot of fill in the hope it would be solid and transmit the energy to the egg shell.

description.text:
What is an Egg Topper?

An egg topper is a device that is designed to create a round hole in the top of a soft boiled egg so it can be spooned out for a lovely breakfast. I don't think I ever had a soft boiled egg before last weekend... I was trying to find something unique to add to Thingiverse and this seemed like it would be a fun challenge. Most egg toppers are metal... will it work? I think this is a definite "must print" because the testing is so fun!!!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

95%

Notes:

I used ABS but I think PLA is more rigid and would probably work better. I used a lot of fill in the hope it would be solid and transmit the energy to the egg shell.

Random build notes...

The design uses a rubber band to create the powerful smacking motion that cracks the round hole in the egg. Similar to commercial toppers, you often have to snap the egg a few times to separate the top shell. On occasion another part of the egg cracks.

I think the main design improvement would be creating a sharper cutting edge. I postponed the sharp edge when I was having problems with bed adhesion. It does work as-is but a sharper edge would probably yield a cleaner cut/break. The goal is to create a perfectly round hole.

Have fun!

author: kkendall

description.text:
PlotClock build based on Joo's original & Harlan's modifications

Modifications:
Expanded body for greater stability/durability
changed arms & wiper
made to use small screws I had on hand
holds a Quartet marker
use 10D nail for pivot on lift axis, little plug to keep it in if it's loose...
Mouser ears on body because one edge was lifting off my platform

note: error in comments for calibration as per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:931498
// When in calibration mode, adjust the NULL-values so that the servo arms are at all times perpendicular NOT PARALLEL

Lift servo was reversed, I copied the section of code out of the sketch Harlan posted pertaining to lift only and pasted it over the original... to reverse the one servo.

Otherwise, I plan on using an Ardweeny as the brain, by expanding the case I should now be able to fit the brain in the box also. I haven't yet built a board for it with the pins and power filtration... likely I'll have to do it over again bigger as that's the way it works.

I am running it currently with an arduino duemilanove. Using USB power for the brains and a separate USB wall wart to power the servos. First attempts to use USB power only resulted in resets and strange action. I'm guessing I will need to add some caps to filter out the noise from the steppers.

I think the handwriting gets worse with each generation. I had hoped stabilizing the servo arm with two pivot points would make the handwriting better but it looks like I'll really just need to learn to code the font better if I want to do that.

description.text:
These test parts were made to test the function of the connectors with minimum waste. Tolerances on these parts are 0.05mm making them difficult to put together if the print quality is not adequate and impossible if any flaws occur.

Reducing the side tabs by 0.25 (0.025 ?) fixed the fit issue and the latest improvement was a reduction in vertical height.

These were the 2nd and 3rd prints I ever made.

The end use file is the final working version that fits together smoothly and tightly with a quarter turn.

Printer:

M 200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

user defined / solid

Notes:

Supports are not required and may interfere with fit. These were first run designs and have extremely tight tolerances.
Designed with 123 Design. Designed from scratch for use in modular parts printed on SMALL printer.

Easy to print, and quite strong. The hook on top is sized for a 13.0 mm diameter round shaft; scale your print to match the size on your seat.

When printed on its side as shown it can be very strong, especially if you set a high number of perimeters. I printed with PETG using two perimeters and the hooks were strong enough to hold my computer backpack. Next time I'll print with 3 or 4 perimeters. Also use a high infill for strength. PETG favors higher extrusion temperatures to enhance the fusion of layers.

The vehicle in the photos is a 2016 Ford F-150 supercab pickup truck. The posts for the head rests were 13 mm in diameter.

UPDATE July 2017: I added extended versions for thicker seats.

18650 battery holder, hols up to 4 batteries with 2 ~0.25" diameter holes in front and back for a ~0.2" diameter magnet, if one wants to have multiple holders to alien with each other ( if oriented properly) as shown in one of the pictures.

It was difficult for me to get a wrench in to tighten the lock nut on the Trinus Z axis home stop with the enclosure in place. This finger wrench slips over the head of the screw, allowing you to adjust the height with a screwdriver in one hand and tighten the nut with the other hand.

The door fasteners on my bandsaw failed a while ago. These replace the plastic parts that failed. Simply re-use the original bolts. I had to hammer them through so the knurled section of the bolt fits in the hole. They're much more solid than the originals and I don't see them failing again in the life of the saw.

Today I needed to drill eight holes in the ceiling, so I decided to buy a 2D bubble level indicator and print a mounting for it to ensure that the holes are perfectly upwards directed. The mounting is fixed by an M3 button head screw, the bubble leveller by 10mm Spax type self drilling screws (id=3mm). It took me two trys to come to these dimensions. Soon I will also post a design for a capsule bubble level (Dosenlibelle in german, hope I translated it right). The inner diameter is designed for a Bosch uneo maxx, simply adapt the mounting bracket dimenstion if your drill requires something else than 35mm for a collar mounting bracket.  
This works for drilling in the ceiling or into the ground. For drilling to walls you need only the one level indicator which is orthogonal to the drilling axis. It would have to be rotated 90 degrees around y.  
Have fun with it!  
PS: please note, that I enlarged the space of the M3 nut and also the rim around it, to ensure that the design I posted won't break at the same point where my second try broke (as seen on the picture).  
Update: so, today the can level indicator arrived. Problem is, that it only works with the bottom facing down. So it is not usable overhead for drilling in the ceiling. Good news is that I successfully tested this design and it works great. One has to stop drilling for reading the levels, but it really avoids that you drill anything else as a right angle.

You'll need one M3 20mm screw and nut, two self drilling screws with 10mm bolt length and an inner Diameter of 2mm. Besides that, you can buy the bubble level maybe in your local hardware store, I got it from Bauhaus. Then simply screw on the 2D bubble level, attach it to the shaft of your drill, check the alignment and fix it with the M3.  
As mentioned in the description: a much simpler solution is on its way with the can bubble level. This will be cheaper, faster to make and easier to read.

description.text:
I really liked this design... My son had a large jar of spiders. On occasion he would go on fly hunts to feed the spiders. I had a great idea to improve his habitat and hopefully rid our yard of flies. I printed a new lid for the jar with an inverted funnel (a common fly trap design). I also added a top so he could control when flies could enter. I figured that if we had the right bait the flies would voluntarily feed my son's spiders.

During our test it caught a few flies. Perhaps the flies detected the web because it didn't seem as effective as a normal trap. My son let the spiders go because he didn't like the stinky fly bait in the bottom of the jar. My wife really didn't like any part of it. I was able to dig the parts out of the trash a few times but haven't seen them in months.

An improved design might add some structure to prevent the spiders from spinning webs on the entrance. A removable bottom for cleaning would also be a nice addition.

description.text: This is a cup holder insert I whipped up that fits in the front compartment of the factory 60-series center console. It has two cup holders and a center slot to hold a smartphone vertically. The cup holders securely hold cans up to 23oz, 20oz soda bottles, and anything else up to 72mm in diameter. The phone slot holds my Galaxy S6 with no case with plenty of wiggle room, and should fit cases up to 72mm wide and 10mm thick. It could probably be scaled to 102-103% for a little extra room, but I haven't tested that yet. It's secured in the compartment by velcro, but double-sided foam tape or magnetic tape would also work. I also lined the bottom of each section with adhesive foam to reduce noise from my aluminum water bottle vibrating, which is optional but recommended. Enjoy!

Notes:

I rotated it 2 degrees with supports underneath to print the top in a single layer. This is optional, but makes for a nicer surface finish depending on the layer height you use.

print_settings.Notes:: Structural rigidity is essential, and solid infill should be used.  The part is designed to crack open slightly at the pointy end, expanding inside the wall when the screw is inserted, and solid infill helps it keep its integrity during this process.  Maintain adequately high printing temperatures so you do not experience delamination defects.

description.text:
These are auger-style drywall anchors. They appear to me under my printing results to be sturdier than any other auger-style drywall anchor I've used. I will not certify a strength rating because your printing results and drywall conditions may vary, but the shape is quite robust. Significantly smaller commercial ones of similar shapes are rated for 75lbs on loads flush with the wall.

Instructions for use:

1) Make a little pilot hole. (You can drill, or just twist a screwdriver through drywall for this.) Make sure you're not in front of a stud, as anchors will not go into a stud.
2) Use the Phillips tip to screw the anchor directly into the drywall until it is flush with the surface.
3) Place what you are mounting and screw the metal screw into the hole centered in the Phillips tip of the anchor.
4) As the screw enters, the anchor will split open slightly on the inside part of the drywall, wedging it tightly in place.

I've often experienced the problem of some excess force removing an old anchor from a wall leaving a hole larger than the old anchors that were used. This requires either extensive effort to repair that part of the wall or if possible moving what was hung to a new spot. Or, you can simply print significantly larger anchors to fit in the new larger hole, which is what motivated this design. The included stl files are for anchors 20mm in diameter. Feel free to customize to your preferred sizing.

OpenSCAD Note: Download augeranchor.scad and v2 or higher of my threading library from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322 Rename the library download file to "threads.scad". In the future I am likely to only update the main threading library with updates to the threading routines, and I might not actively merge those changes with the customizer_version here.

Version 2 (2017-04-10) corresponds to the v2.1 auger thread bug fix of threads.scad. The resulting anchor should be effectively the same with both updated.

description.text:
If you have any of the old 70's Mattel Electronics sports handheld games this is a replacement battery cover for them. It was designed off a Mattel Electronics Baseball game but they all used the same cover. Print it in the closet color filament you have to match your game and enjoy.

Note: I did have to print this with supports for the tongue to come out correct. I used supports every 1mm but you could probably get away with 2mm or 2.5mm spacing. Also I printed this in PLA and it is much stiffer than the original plastic the game housing is made of so be careful when removing so you don't break your game.

description.text:
A few months ago we bought an adjustable foundation for our bed. It is a clone of the Reverie 4m. Our ceiling fan had a wall mount that we mounted on the wall behind the bed which made it really convenient to reach for both of us when we were in bed and this remote seemed like a perfect candidate to do the same thing. The shape of the remote did not lend itself to using a command strip or similar since the back of the remote is not flat. So I came up with something that works great and allows easy removal if needed.

This is not super robust, the side walls are 1mm thick, mainly so that the buttons on the remote remain easy to reach and not recessed. However it handles the remote and frequent middle of the night button pushes without a problem. If you decide you need to thicken the walls up. The tinker link is directly below.

title: Lulzbot Taz 6 Vibration Damper Compatible Y motor Mount

description.text:
This is a Lulzbot Taz 6 printer upgrade. In order to install a vibration damper to the TAZ 6 you need to raise the 8 points of contacts up. Rather than doing that and potentially bending something, I decided to create a model and lift the motor mount up by 6mm so that the Y motor still has the same clearance with the ground when vibration damper is installed.

You do NOT need to change the position of the pulley. The motor will be exactly where it was before you install the damper.

comments.text: Has Lulzbot implemented this into the production models? or is it just similar to what is already there?
comments.author: zerstoyer17

comments.text:
I designed it to be almost the same as the original one but more clearance to add the damper. If you add damper to your original one motor will hit the ground.
If Lulzbot incorporated my design, idk about that :D

description.text:
This is a CNC file for coasters I made for Boosted Boards.

You can see them being made at the link below
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L1L8BGaNbN0

Playing around with Pythagoras, and this is another piece of work that belongs in the advances of the Architectural norm that is design today.

People were jaw dropped (well the rich and the well to do in the crowd were), when they would see architectural drawings that looked like nothing before.

As you can see, in the day all these architects needed was some overinflated highly priced piece of toy software on their Apple macs (what else)... and they would sit there all day month after month typing highly advanced complicated code (lol) and would render them as mac only Tiffs.

Presentations would take weeks to organise because they would bring in boxes of floppy disks that were mac format only, and spend huge amounts of money on the presentation macintosh (an LC2 I think), with extra zip drives attatched to make sure data wasn't lost.

you get the pic.
This is a movable piece I created. Enjoy!

description.text:
A FAN MADE version of a mortar carrier based off of the Zerber Chassis. Please note, I do not play the game, nor do I know the lore. I simply enjoy the art style of these models and enjoy building/painting them.

If someone ever builds one of these, please let me know. I would love to see any paints or custom things added to it.

Thanks to KJdidit for the request!

Using an Epilog Mini 24 laser cutter, laser engraved map of Alaska.

Materials

  • Epilog Mini 24
  • Cermark (this bonds with the metal to leave the black marks behind) - I attempted molly which is a lot cheaper, but it wouldn't bond with the galvanized steel.
  • Galvanized Steel Plate: I got them from the roofing section at home depot, mine is 12" x 8", and it was like $1.00.
  • Lunch Ice packs: (the metal is so thin it'll warp under the heat of the laser. To prevent this I taped thin ice packs to the back to keep the temperature down)

Laser Settings
60% power, 70% speed, Engrave All

description.text: This as a flying disc modeled after an Innova Disc Golf Champion TL Fairway Driver (7 5 0 1). :) I designed it from scratch and it's certainly not exact. The attached STL is 210mm in diameter which is the same diameter as the Innova. This disc is flat on the top as where the Innova is curved up to a flat surface. The black disc in the picture and video was scaled to 80% so it would fit on my print bed and it was modeled with 24 sides. The attached STL was modeled with 999 sides. Enjoy! Look! It flys! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ft0o8aDtNak
Scale it to fit your printer bed if you need to when you slice it. I sliced it in Slic3r at 80%. If you have 200mm of space on your print bed, then divide 200 by 210 and you get 95%.

comments.text: Printed it in PLA and it works, it curves much harder than most of my discs but it does actually work. I got par 3 on a short hole using only that disc, I was impressed. I'm going to reprint it in TPU to make it more of a putter. Thanks!

title: Snow Capped Mountain with a Curved Train Pathway

description.text:
This is a modified hill based on Monte Cervino by gluetolf. I upscaled the model to a size of 27.4 L X 27.4 B X 23.7 H in cms. I also created a passage way for a Lego Train to pass through. You may either print the entire thing as a single piece or I have also shared split pieces to print and join them. But please make sure you keep the same settings and use the same printer while printing, otherwise you will have to go through my post printing steps at the bottom to rectify any gaps that occur.

Happy Printing !

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Z18

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Remember to pause the print cycle just near the top so that you can load the white filament after the green to give the snow cap effect.

If you are printing the top portion separately then you must be sure when to pause the load the white filament.

Intermediate Post Processing

Since I used the Z18 and the Replicator+ to Print the split parts, while joining there was a mismatch. I used quick glue to stick them together and then used modeling clay (Green One in my case) to fill up the gaps and make it look natural as shown int he images.
I used a licenses version of Ansys Spaceclaim to create the pathway for the train passage.

title: Cord Hook Replacement / Upgrade for Dirt Devil Upright Vaccum Model 086925
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a Dirt Devil (Model 086925) upright vacuum cleaner and the upper cord hook broke. I designed and modeled this in Blender and printed it to serve as a functional upper cord hook replacement / upgrade. Why is it an upgrade? The original cord hook was fixed in place and I couldn't quickly turn it downward and pull off the whole cord wrap off. Now I can.

The original cord hook was glued on. I gently hacksawed the broken cord hook off. After printing this it will fit sort of snug over the base, but it will rotate. You can either apply glue and slide it on, or you can use a 3/8" screw to keep it from coming off, thereby allowing you to rotate it to remove the cord.

I hope that someone finds this useful. A lot of time and PLA went into designing this thing. If this design blesses your life in some way, feel free to favor me with a tip as thanks. Gratuities are not required, but are definitely appreciated. You can tip me any amount that you would like here: https://www.paypal.me/brysonjack
Make sure to include a comment telling me which design it is. Thanks in advance.

title: [WIP] E3D V6 Clamp with 30mm cooler mount for Hypercube

description.text:
So, my cheap knockoff e3d v6 came with a cooling duct that wasnt seated properly. And, well, it rattled itself a bit loose, touched the heater core and of course melted - Which didnt really improve the rattling...

So here is the prototype for a cooling duct that mounts directly to Tech2c's bowden mount - and most likely to a lot of remixes as well.

This thing is a work in progress! Use at your own risk.

The depth of the mounting holes is the same as in the original, so the mounting screws will still work.

The holes for the 30mm cooler are meant to be self tapping, which works if you apply a bit of force (please use galvanized steel screws or better!).

Once screwed down, the cooler is tighly in place.

I've printed a prototype with cheap PLA, and at 210°C, it didnt melt, deform or even heat up - I still strongly suggest you print this out of PETG or better yet ABS... Kapton Insulation on your hotend might improve stability and reliability even further.

Addendum on temperatures: Tested this with the same PLA at 240°C nozzle temperature and still no melting occured.

I will try to improve this further, there is currently a huge air gap between the cooler mount and the heat break - The heatbreak still stays cool to the touch, but yet again: Please be careful.

author: jpotegal

title: Monoprice Select Mini Heated Bed Repair/Upgrade

description.text:
This is a video of my repair/upgrade to the Monoprice Select Mini heated bed. I have had issues with the wires under the heated bed wearing out, getting stuck and chaffing on the belt. I decided to solve these issues by rerouting the wires externally in flexible conduit.

Video Link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W1MqNMbGtDY

I used 18awg High Flexibility Silicone wire for the heating element, 24awg speaker wire for the thermistor leads and some wire conduit material to encase it.

I also used some cork to insulate the bed. This has really stabilized the bed temperature. I used Kapton tape to secure it to the bed instead of stuffing foam board under it. This way I don't have to worry about the foam putting pressure on the bed and distorting it as there is still an air gap under the cork.

author: jpotegal

description.text:
Thanks for leemes for the great bottle opener design.

We added a whistle because we can! We are using this model as a giveaway at makerfairs.

For editing we didn't like to mess with the stl, so we remodeled the file in fusion 360 and exported it as a .stp for you.

Update 15.7.2017: added a version with a keyhole

This is an improved version of this thing
I modified the air channel from the fan to the heatsink. It is a bit wider on the left and more then a bit on the right. The asymetrical setup is done as I want it to fit between the heatsink (of course) and this BLTouch support.
The original version of the shroud works fine, but I wanted to reduce the resistance in the airchannel through the heatsink while still keeping the flex for easy removal/installation and keeping the Volcano completely accessible for nozzle changes.
The holes for the screws are made to cut M3 thread in it or to use self-cutting plastic screws. Of course you can use a 3mm drill ....

Works out perfectly :).
I've printed it in Polycarbonate (see pictures) and it has enough flex to be easily removed and enough bite and support to stay nicely in place.

Print settings used : 0,6mm nozzle, 0,32mm layers, support needed (but not that much)
I've printed it in ABS @240°C with bed @110°C and PC @310°C with bed @125°C

author: fairymoth

description.text:
This is a rotation to linear motion transforming device that I invented, designed and built for a Robotics competition at Umeå University, Sweden. The device is going to be used for popping balloons by mounting a needle on the anterior end of the shaft.

In addition to the 3d printed parts, you will need:
  • x1 DC Motor (see example link below)
  • x2 623 Bearings
  • x1 LM6UU Bushing
  • x4 M4 Threaded rods á 120mm
  • x1 M6 Smooth rod á 65mm
  • x8 M4 Nylock nuts
  • x8 M4 Nuts (+2 for the mounting holes)
  • x2 M3 Screw á 16mm
  • x2 M3 Screw á 12mm
  • x1 M3 Screw á 20mm
  • x1 M3 Threaded rod á 45mm
  • x2 M3 Washers
  • x6 M3 Nuts (preferably 3 Nylock nuts for the bearing mounting holes)

The DC Motor that I used

I advise you to put washers between the M3 screws/nuts and 3d models, since it decreases the wear and tear that may occur from clamping.

I have included a dwf file in the download to make it easier for you to know where every component should go.

I wish I had made a tutorial in how to build this from scratch, but I simply forgot to make one.

I have included a no-text version of the anterior mount.

Hope you like it!

title: HE280 Hotend Whip Retention Clip for Rostock Max V3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 2018-02-01: I got tired of clipping and reinstalling zip ties, so I designed two different locking parts. The TPU one is for when you're using an HE280 with the fan shrouds above it. TPU is flexible enough for you to scoot it around the fan shrouds and on to the clip. The other on is for effectors that do not have the high fan shrouds. You can print that one out of PLA or whatever. Either one just slips over the clip once connected and prevents it from coming loose.

UPDATE 2017-05-08: So, has anyone else made one? There have been like 30 downloads and I'm curious how it's working for you. If you print this and use it, please leave a comment. :) Thanks!

If you have an HE280 hot end on your Rostock, you may have noticed that the wire whip plug does not have any retention mechanism. On two occasions I had the hotend get disconnected from the printer. Once it resulted in a thermal runaway due to the fact that the heater stayed connected while the thermister was disconnected. On the other occasion, the plug came loose during a z-probe resulting in the hotend being driven into the bed until I hit the red button.

These incidents lead me to consider methods to prevent it. This replacement cover and retention clip for your HE280 will allow you to ensure that your hotend stays plugged in.

I have printed and tested both of these objects on my printer and they perform as designed. The heat shrink on the wire whip does impede the clip slightly, so you have to squeeze the clip to get it to engage. Although I think that the clip works adequately, I have added a zip tie around the clip as a failsafe.

The HE280 is stock on the Rostock Max V3 and can be added to any Rostock Max as an upgrade.

UPDATE: I realized that I uploaded an old cover file without enough clearance to insert the clip. v2 fixes this, but if you already printed it, no fear, you can modify it with a razor blade or file. I'm actually running v1 on my printer with no issues.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle; 0.2mm layer height

Infill:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I printed the cover with PLA using support everywhere. The retention clip, I printed with no support in PETG for greater flexibility, but maybe PLA would have been stiffer and hold the whip better. On my printer, I used a zip tie (or one of the newly uploaded locks) around the retention clip to ensure that it doesn't slip.
Thanks to SeeMeCNC providing models of all of the Rostock parts, I started with the HE280 cover and cut out the space for the clip and then designed a clip to fit into the space.

comments.text:
It's a little on the large-ish size for a 200mm printer, i scaled mine to 80% to make it still quite large, but all the parts fit quite comfortably on the print bed. I think the only real change to running gear is i'll have to drill out the channels for the shaft tubes a bit. Done printing the hull, now doing all the superstructure bits! This is a great model, I love the look and styling. Can't wait to get mine in the water :-)
Printing everything in Inland PLA, 20% infill, except the rudders, which are 80% for strength.
comments.author: buhatkj

comments.text: I am just printing it at 100% scale in PLA, I have so far only printed the hull 5 section which has taken something like 23 hours to print at a layer height of 0.3mm and an infill of 20%. I am am using the slicers defaults of 3 top solid layers, 3 bottom solid layers and 3 outline/permimeter shells but just this front section alone weighs an awful lot. Can I ask what settings you are using? I started off using Simplify3D but because of issues with the hull 1 section I am just switching over to Cura and so will likely re do hull 5 again.

description.text:
hey ppl, This was modeled after mario world for snes made 100% from scratch using reference photos not from game files since they dont exist for this system..

As the download is now its 4 Grams,45 mins print time at .1 layer height,and 20%infill

feel free to make it bigger i made mine 8 grams by scaling it up 28%..

build it with supports with the back of the hat touching the buildplate so the face doesnt have any supports on it....( unless someone has a better method pls post a comment)
you can refer to the video for how to orient it with supports...
took me a few hours to make it hope you like it..

For painting i used model paint here are the colors i used..
Engine red, Flat white, beige and the black is the color i printed it in

Luigis coming next..

happy printing

comments.text:
Printed beautifully on my CR-10 S5.
Gameoutlaw, you need to create supports before printing, as is true of most files.
comments.author: Poitaman

comments.text: So this model did not work well for me. First of all the panda itself has its legs on the ground, but not its butt. So it prints the legs first, works its way up to where the butt height, and just drops the melted plastic down, it doesnt form from the base up, because the butt is higher than the base. Secondly the ears have no supports and only have a tiny pin prick of themselves touching the base. Then the ear to the left (the right ear) is further down than the other one, meaning it prints that on out, and just drops the other ear from about a half a centimeter up. Overall, nice design but very poorly executed.
comments.author: Gameoutlaw

comments.text:
hi Gameoutlaw,
What printer are you printing on? Does it has a print with support function /option? If the function is not on as you said it will not print in air.
The panda was printed on a upbox+ and a upboxmini using this.
I don't understand how you are saying that the design is poorly executed?
I would be happy to put up a video of the print to show how well it prints if you like.
comments.author: Gameoutlaw

author: Chelovek

description.text: MITSUBISHI XB 669338-1

This is a tripod phone holder for devices with around 5 inches display.

The bottom part is configured to allow a nut to be mounted. Tripods usually have a 1/4-20 inches screw thread (Wikipedia link). It was not so easy for me to find locally a suitable nut so I tried to print it by myself. It surprisingly works and I included its STL in this thing.

I printed this using PLA, but any rigid material could be used.

Mount a spring

Drill a 1mm hole on the top and bottom components, in order to mount an expansion spring that will help in keeping the phone stick to the holder.
I used a 3.5mm long spring, you can easily find them in a local hardware store.

Glue components

Put the top and bottom component inside one side of the body and glue up the bottom component with the body.

Finally, glue up the other side of the body paying attention to keep the top part sliding.
CH341 programmer enclosure just to protect the electronic parts

author: greekpet

description.text:
The long awaited radial engine has arrived!
The next issue in my line of motor models, a demonstration model of a five piston radial motor. Please leave me some comments on improvements you would like to see!
It looks like a steam punk version of a Stark arc reactor! Hmmm...

I have uploaded a complete model and individual components.
Scale to your hearts content...hint hint Replicator people!
Print all components with exception of pistons at 100% infill.
Use body components 2.0
Assemble pistons to rods with a hunk of filament or something else 3mm.
Attach piston rods to connector.
Prepare flywheel by inserting axle.
Mount assembly on fly wheel.
Then assemble body around piston/flywheel assembly starting with the body part to hold flywheel in place.
Secure each body segment with choice of adhesive, I use Krazy glue.
Done! Updates:
Radial 2.0 Now has a dial on the back to turn the mechanism easier!
New video at http://youtu.be/f4uudyJQ32s New body parts 2.0 containing alignment ribs to ease assembly and stronger interface of parts
Connector and rods file has built in support
Longer drive shaft on the fly wheel
Better tolerances on the piston and rod assembly
Piston depression detail
Stabilizing arm
Cap for rod assembly
Various filleted edges
Complete model now has pins holding pistons on (can't believe I missed that)
Two body files to scale as large as you can: A and B body piece types (be sure to scale the other components the same amount)
More fun! Printing results:
As shown in the pictures I printed the body without support and only had a couple loops. I was very surprised as the overhang is pretty extreme. I am going to print one separately and see if it turns out better. Printing result update:
I added alignment ribs to the body components and they make assembly much easier, see the photos. Video link:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_IAEBPesCE

Not all the models need support structures. Certain models can be printed without support structures. But for certain ones, you would need support structures.
NGSS CCSS

Machine Drawings Machine drawing deals with the information regarding a part or component of a machinery and it also has information about the way it should be made. A machine drawing generally gives all the external and internal details of the machine component from which it can be manufactured. The machining symbols, tolerances, bill of material, etc. are specified on the drawing.

Machine Drawing Step 1
Take a printout of the drawing sheets on paper Step 2
Ask the student to use a modeling software (any licensed version of AutoCAD, Fusion 360, Spaceclaim, Rhino, etc. can be used) and start with the line sketch Step 3
The dimensions for the line sketch are all given in the drawing sheets Step 4
Using the line sketch, ask the student to extrude the surfaces created in three dimensional bodies Step 5
Using various tools like pull, move, fill, combine, split, chamfer, rounds, tapers, shell, offset curves, etc. produce the shapes of the machine components in each object Step 6
Create a drawing sheet for every machine component and lay down the dimensions Step 7
Save the file in various formats suitable for CNC and 3D Printing machines Step 8
Load the .STL saved file in MakerBot Print Step 9
Use the printer parameters specified and print the file

Machine Drawing Materials Needed Include
  • Laptop or Desktop PC with configuration related to the Modeling Software
  • Licensed or Education Licensed Modeling Software's
  • 3D Printer
  • Software for Slicing
1 Hour Lesson per Machine Drawing

description.text:
This is a custom pellet hopper and fan mount for the Filastruder filament extruder kit.  
The hopper is designed to accept a clear plastic storage tube that you can get at the hardware store, allowing you to easily gauge when to refill.  Its angled bottom helps keep pellets from getting stuck.  
The custom fan mount replaces the block of wood included with the kit and is designed to clamp around the nozzle insulation.  It accepts a longer length of copper pipe than in the default kit setup.

title: Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

description.text:
Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

Upgrade your Original Prusa i3 MK2 to use E3D's Titan Aero!

Use the complete range of E3D Heater Blocks & Nozzles | http://e3d-online.com/

Select the Reach-Around Fan Duct based on the body size of the Stepper Motor you are fitting. If you are fitting the original Prusa supplied motor you will need the 39mm Reach-Around Fan Duct.

Fully supports the Prusa Auto-Bed-Leveling, however you do need to preposition the bed along the Y-Axis using the Back Spacer.stl. You loose approximately 15mm along the Y-Axis but gain 8mm along the Z-Axis. The X-Axis is unaffected.

Consult the Prusa_Reference_Images.zip file for additional views and guidance on routing the cables and wires.

Flash the included prusa_mk2_titan_aero.hex
Use X-Loader to flash | http://russemotto.com/xloader/

E3D Shopping List.

Print with your favourite thermoplastic | http://e3d-online.com/All-Filament

A Selection of assorted Metric Square Nuts(3 x M3).
